attributes.title: Chinese herbal medicine combination therapy for patients with steroid-dependent ulcerative colitis: study protocol for a systematic riview and meta-analysis

q1.value: Chinese herbal medicine combination therapy for patients with steroid-dependent ulcerative colitis: study protocol for a systematic review and meta-analysis

q2.value: Qiaobo Ye, ZhipengHu, MaoyiYang, Kaihua Qin, Yingguang Zhou

q3.value:
Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic non-specific inflammation disease characterized by abdominal pain and diarrhea. The prevalence of UC in north America and Europe is 24.30/10000 and 19.20/10000 respectively. The prevalence of UC in Asia and the Middle East is lower, about 6.30/10000. The prevalence of UC in mainland China is about 11.6/10000. Many complications occur in the later stage of UC, including toxic megacolon, intestinal perforation, lower gastrointestinal hemorrhage, intraepithelial neoplasia  and colorectal cancer. The recurrence of UC brings a heavy economic and health burden to the health system and patients.
At present, the clinical treatment of UC includes 5-ASA (such as sulfasalazine, sulfasalazine, etc.), glucocorticoids (such as prednisone, hydrocortisone, etc.), immunosuppressants (azathioprine, cyclosporine, etc.), biological agents and surgical treatment. However, the overall effect of these treatment is not satisfactory. Among these treatments, steroid is an effective treatment for UC, especially for moderate to severely UC. However, steroids therapy has some defects. First, steroids therapy can only be used to induce remission, but not as a maintain therapy. Secondly, the condition is easy to relapse after the cessation of treatment, and the patient eventually becomes steroid-dependent UC. There are many adverse effects in the long-term use of steroid.
Chinese herbal medicine (CHM) has a long history in treating UC[ ]. In China, many steroids-dependent UC patients receive CHM for adjuvant treatment, hoping to reduce the dosage of hormone and adverse effects. Many clinical studies about the effect of CHM for steroids-dependent UC have been carried out. In these studies, traditional Chinese medicine can improve the condition of patients. However, due to the small sample size and the defects of research design, these clinical studies have failed to give a comprehensive and definite answer to the application of CHM in steroid-dependent UC.
In this study, we will systematically summarize the clinical evidence of CHM in treating steroid-dependent UC. For clinicians, this study will provide evidence-based guidance for the clinical application of CHM on steroid-dependent UC. For researchers, this study will point out the existing gaps in the current research of CHM in the treatment of steroid-dependent UC, and provide direction for the future research.

q4.value: Traditional Chinese medicine combined with conventional treatment is safe and effective, the condition of patients with steroids-dependent ulcerative colitis will improve.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This will be a systematic review and meta-analysis of all eligible studies.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: Three English database including PubMed, Embase, Cochrane Library Central Register of Controlled Trials and four Chinese databases including China National Knowledge Infrastructure (CNKI) database, Wanfang Data Knowledge Service Platform, the VIP information resource integration service platform (cqvip), China Biology Medicine Disc (Sino Med) will be searched from their inception to May 2020 with a language limitation of English and Chinese.

q13.value: The sample size will be at least 100 participants.

question.value:
main outcome:steroid-free remission rate
secondary outcomes:1.Total clinical effective rate.
2. Incidence of adverse events.
3. Disease activity index (modified Mayo score).
4. Results of enteroscopy (Baron score).
5. Mucosa (geboes index score).
There will be no limitation about measures.

Data analysis will be conducted using Review Manager Version 5.3 and Stata 14.0 software. The effect measure of binary variable will be expressed as risk ratio (RR) and 95% confidence interval (CI), and calculated by mantel Haenszel (M-H) method. For continuous variables, 95% CI and mean difference (MD) or standardized mean difference (SMD) will be used. We will use Cochrane X2 and I2 tests[ ] to complete the heterogeneity analysis of the study. When P < .05 and I2>50%, we will use the random effect model. When P > .05 and I2<50%, the heterogeneity can be ignored, indicating the included studies are homogeneous and the differences between them can be ignored, we will use fixed effect model to calculate the effect size. If there is a substantial heterogeneity and quantitative synthesis is not appropriate, we will conduct qualitative analysis, and the results will be presented in the form of tables and figures.

attributes.title: Interest Groups, Policy Representation and the Legitimacy of Governance

q1.value: Interest Groups, Policy Representation and the Legitimacy of Governance

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Project abstract: Adopting policy that is regarded as fair in both procedural and substantive terms is important for policy-makers to ensure the legitimacy of their decisions. While interest groups are often involved in policy-making in both national and international governance, it is contested whether they strengthen or weaken its legitimacy. On the one hand, consultation of interest groups may lead to more inclusive, more legitimate and ‘better’ policy. On the other hand, interest groups might push policy-makers to pursue narrow interests and, thereby, exacerbate public discontent with political decisions. In order to systematically assess how interest group involvement affects the legitimacy of governance, we conduct survey experiments among representative samples of citizens in the UK, the US, Germany and Denmark using a conjoint design with vignettes describing hypothetical policy decisions. We are interested in exploring the role of three factors which might affect both the substantive and procedural legitimacy of specific political decisions: (a) to what extent different types of interest groups were involved in the policy- making process; (b) the alignment of the adopted policies with the preferences of interest groups; and (c) whether these policies were in line with public opinion. We argue that interest group involvement may improve the legitimacy of policy-making in democratic politics depending on the policy preferences and configuration of active interests involved. Our study provides new insights on how citizens judge the potential trade-offs which decision-makers face in responding to citizen and interest group preferences. Moreover, it adds knowledge of how citizens assess the importance of ensuring diversity in the types of interest groups included in policy-making.

q16.value: H1: Citizens’ perceptions of legitimacy are higher when the key interest groups relevant to an issue are invited to submit oral evidence/contribute to a legislative hearing than when they are H2: Citizens’ perceptions of legitimacy are higher when equal numbers of groups representing special and diffuse interests are involved in the policy-making process as compared to having groups representing one of the two types of interest dominate. H2a: Having groups representing special interests dominate has a stronger negative effect on perceived legitimacy than having groups representing diffuse interests dominate. H2b: The negative effect on perceived legitimacy of one interest group type dominating participation is stronger when the policy output goes against the opinion of the group type that is in the minority or not represented. H3: Perceived legitimacy is higher when the public supports the policy and the stronger public support for the policy. H3a: The negative effect on perceived legitimacy of not inviting key stakeholder groups to provide oral evidence is weaker the stronger public support for a policy decision. H3b: The negative effect on perceived legitimacy of one interest group type dominating participation is weaker the stronger public support for a policy decision. H3c: The negative effect on perceived legitimacy of one interest group type dominating participation is weaker in case the public majority is aligned with the group type invited and disagrees with the stakeholders excluded H4: Perceived legitimacy is higher when both types of groups rather than only one of them support the policy output. H4a: The negative impact of adopting a policy decision that goes against the view of one of the two types of interest groups is stronger in cases where special (as opposed to diffuse) interests attain their preferences.

q17.value: We will test our hypothesis through two survey experiments with conjoint designs using vignettes. We conduct two separate experiments with different policy issues within one survey in order to increase our confidence that the findings are generalizable to different policy areas. The issues are presented to respondents in a randomized order. In each of the two experiments, respondents will be presented with a short text explaining a new policy that has been debated and either passed or rejected by parliament. In the description, two different types of interest groups are identified as the main stakeholders on the policy issue. It is also stated whether these two types of interests were invited to participate in a consultation process and what decision the decision-makers took. Finally, respondents are told whether the decision was in line with public opinion and with the position of the two types of interest groups. The survey will be fielded among representative samples of the population in Denmark, Germany, the UK, and the US (N=3,000 per country). We use non-probability quota sampling to ensure that our country samples are representative of the population with respect to age groups, gender and region. In our design, the random assignment of values of each attribute is independent from the values on the other attributes. The method allows us to treat each attribute, e.g. public opinion or interest group involvement, as a random variable whose effects on the outcome we can estimate while controlling for the attributes – this is the Average Marginal Component Effect (AMCE). In addition, we can compare the strength of the AMCEs of the different attributes. Finally, we can estimate the effects of one attribute at specific values of another, i.e. conditional AMCEs, to test the hypotheses positing interaction effects. We will use OLS regressions to estimate AMCEs and conditional AMCEs in order to analyse how the experimental treatments affect legitimacy beliefs and how they interact with each other and respondent characteristics, as hypothesized above.

q23.value: No ethics approval is required by the University of Copenhagen. Before the survey respondents are told that the study is anonymous/confidential and confirm their responses may be stored and accessed by researchers. Afterwards, respondents are debriefed.

q27.value: The survey has been designed and programmed by the Investigators and is fielded by Qualtrics, which is responsible for the acquisition of the samples.

q31.value: The researchers have the right to use and publish all the data collected by Qualtrics.

attributes.title: The Everyday State: Measuring the Power of Nationally Unifying Symbols

q1.value: The Everyday State: Measuring the Power of Nationally Unifying Symbols

q5.value: I’d like to acknowledge the generous funding of Iowa State’s Lucken Faculty Fellowship to allow this work to proceed, as well as research assistants Jiayi Zheng, Grace Arganbright,, and Araceli Lopez-Valdivia for their help with survey construction and testing., An earlier version of this research was presented at the Asian Studies Association of Australia’s annual meeting in Sydney, July 2018.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Previous survey work has found that subnational identity – love of one’s state or province – is surprisingly high and nearly identically distributed in China and the United States. These similarities persist despite the vastly different political systems in the two countries, and despite a concerted effort to build subnational identity in the US and an even more intense effort to stamp out subnational identity in China. This study will test whether subnational identity can be activated in both countries using an experimental treatment, and also will serve as a measure of what demographic factors are associated with higher or lower levels of subnational attachment.

q16.value: H1: US respondents will have higher levels of subnational attachment than Chinese respondents, holding other factors constant. H2: Respondents primed with their state/province hero statue and blurb (Treatment group) will identify more with their state/province identity than their national one (compared with the control group and holding other factors constant). H3: Respondents in the American South, and particularly in Texas, will have on average greater identification with their states than respondents in other national regions. (This is hypothesized to be true for respondents in South China as well) H4: In the US, fans of state sports teams – especially strong fans – will have higher levels of subnational attachment than non-fans, ceteris paribus. H4A: In China, respondents who return frequently to their “ancestral villages” will have higher levels of subnational attachment than those who do not return, ceteris paribus. H5: Higher levels of trust in local and state institutions and neighborhoods are associated with higher levels of subnational attachment. Lower levels of local trust, conversely, are associated with lower levels of subnational attachment. H5A: Higher levels of trust in national and federal institutions are associated with higher levels of national patriotism. Lower levels of national trust, conversely, are associated with lower levels of national patriotism. H6: In the US, Democrats will be less likely to have strong levels of national attachment than Republicans; “Strong” Republicans will display the highest level of national patriotism and “strong” Democrats the highest level of subnational identity. H6A: Communist Party members will have stronger national attachment and weaker subnational attachment than non-Party members, holding other factors constant. H7: Given findings from the existing literature and many people’s cynicism about politics, the better educated and better informed respondents are associated with lower levels of both national and subnational pride. H8: Responses collected in both countries’ second round of data collection – during and surrounding both countries’ major national holidays – will show higher levels of national attachment and lower levels of subnational attachment compared to other rounds.

q17.value: Each respondent, after selecting their state/province of residence, will receive either a national treatment (in the US case, George Washington) or a state/province treatment. The state/province treatment consists of a short paragraph about a state hero, with accompanying picture of a statue or monument to that hero. All respondents will then receive a short survey about their level of patriotism and subnational attachment, plus a number of control variables. I will also test H8 by varying the timing of survey collection to ensure that surveys are collected in three rounds: before, during and after a major national holiday (Independence Day (7/4) in the USA, National Day (10/1) in China)

q19.value: 5200 US respondents across 52 state-level units (50 states plus D.C. & overseas territories @ 100 respondents each), 4080 Chinese respondents across 34 province-level units (@ 120 respondents each)

attributes.title: Perceptions of Security and the Sources of State and Non-State Legitimacy in Post-Conflict Settings

q1.value: Perceptions of Security and the Sources of State and Non-State Legitimacy in Post-Conflict Settings

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: The problem for states with limited capacities is that they must gain legitimacy in order to generate compliance and cooperation, often during or after conflict. This project investigates how de-facto and perceived security provision affects perceptions of the legitimacy of governance actors. In particular, our research seeks to answer two questions: What are the sources of legitimacy in areas of limited statehood? What is the relationship between perceptions of security and legitimacy? We articulate a set of hypotheses about the sources of legitimacy and test them with a survey implemented in Liberia. The study will build on previous research and existing theories about the sources of legitimacy. The project focuses on output-based theories of legitimacy and the extent to which effective governance allow authorities to build perceptions of legitimacy among local populations. Specifically, the project investigates the degree to which perceptions of physical security within local populations can function as a source of legitimacy, since security perceptions are an essential part of effective governance. Moreover, the project will also consider alternative sources of legitimacy such as procedural justice or democratic input-mechanisms. Thereby, the study contributes to the debate about which sources of legitimacy are most relevant and allows for comparisons between varying sources. The project takes the legitimacy of state institutions on different levels in to account (local vs. county-level), but also the legitimacy of UNMIL troops as external actors. Therefore, comparisons between different actors and institutions will be possible. We selected Liberia because the state’s limitations in Liberia make it possible for us to generalize our findings to other settings with limited statehood.

q16.value: H1a: Individual perceptions of procedural justice are positively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive county-level state institutions as legitimate. H1b: Individual perceptions of procedural justice are positively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive local state institutions as legitimate. H1c: Individual perceptions of procedural justice are positively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive UNMIL troops as legitimate. H2a: Individual perceptions of democratic processes as free and fair are positively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive county-level state institutions as legitimate. H2b: Individual perceptions of democratic processes as free and fair are positively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive local state institutions as legitimate. H2c: Individual perceptions of democratic processes as free and fair are positively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive UNMIL troops as legitimate. H3a: Individual perceptions of corruption are negatively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive county-level state institutions as legitimate. H3b: Individual perceptions of corruption are negatively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive local state institutions as legitimate. H3c: Individual perceptions of corruption are negatively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive UNMIL troops as legitimate. H4a: Contact with state institutions is positively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive county-level state institutions as legitimate. H4b: Contact with state institutions is positively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive county-level state institutions as legitimate. H4c: Contact with state institutions is positively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive local state institutions as legitimate. H5a: Contact with state institutions decreases the likelihood that citizens perceive local state institutions as legitimate. H5b: Contact with state institutions increases the likelihood that citizens perceive UNMIL troops as legitimate. H5c: Contact with state institutions decreases the likelihood that citizens perceive UNMIL troops as legitimate. For our main hypothesis, we theorize that when civilians feel more secure, they perceive state institutions and UNMIL troops as more legitimate, conditional on individuals explicitly attributing their security to these actors. H6a: Individual perceptions of security are positively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive county-level state institutions as legitimate. H6b: Individual perceptions of security are positively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive local state institutions as legitimate. H6c: Individual perceptions of security are positively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive UNMIL troops as legitimate. We explicitly test for the conditional aspects of our main hypotheses: H7a: Individuals that explicitly attribute their security to state institutions are more likely than those who do not to perceive county-level state institutions as legitimate. H7b: Individuals that explicitly attribute their security to state institutions are more likely than those who do not to perceive local state institutions as legitimate. H7c: Individuals that explicitly attribute their security to UNMIL are more likely than those who do not to perceive UNMIL as legitimate. We also want to test whether the legitimacy the UNMIL troops possibly enjoyed had positive externalities on state institutions. Since one of the main goals of the UNMIL troops was to help build state institutions and a functioning state-society relationship. These hypotheses help to test one of the core assumptions behind external intervention aiming at state-building. H8a: Citizens that consider UNMIL troops as legitimate are also more likely to perceive county-level state institutions as legitimate. H8b: Citizens that consider UNMIL troops as legitimate are also more likely to perceive local state institutions as legitimate.

q17.value: We will test the hypotheses with an analysis of survey data collected using SMS surveys implemented with Random Digit Dialing (RDD) methods. Our collaborators at Orange Door Research partnered with a firm called GeoPoll, which has a large sample of Liberian phone numbers, which we used to conduct the nationally representative SMS surveys. GeoPoll has established a partnership with Liberian TelCos, which enables GeoPoll to randomly sample from a full mobile subscriber database of network providers, including the ability to draw random, pre-stratified samples for specific sub-national geographic areas. For this project, and under guidance and supervision from Orange Door Research, GeoPoll randomly sampled respondents from its subscriber database according to the geographic specification provided by Orange Door Research. We use county-specific questions in the survey itself to validate the location of each respondent. This is an opt-in survey. Respondents are sent the first initial invitation (consent message) at an agreed upon time. After this first message, sample members that are unresponsive are resent the invitation message once every 24 hours as long as the survey is open or an agreed amount of days after the initial message. Sample members that move past the consent message are sent a reminder message to complete the survey once every 24 hours until they complete the survey. Upon successful completion of the survey, each respondent receives the local equivalent of $0.50 in airtime top-up credit. In order to include individual as well as county-level covariates, we will employ multilevel models to include in our regression. Our primary outcome measures are three sets of questions that asked respondents to say how much they trusted they had in each type of authority (county, community, UNMIL). We will create two variables from the survey to use as a dependent variable: (1) a binary indicator for whether respondents said they had much trust in an authority and (2) an ordinal variable ranging from 0-3 that covers the full range of responses possible. We will use primarily logit models to assess the relationship between our explanatory variables and the binary indicator. From these results, we will derive predicted probabilities for ease of interpretation. We will also conduct ordered logit regression for robustness. As the number of second level units (counties) is rather low, we will focus on robust and rather conservative models such as random intercept models with a limited number of county-level variables included. Should multilevel models turn out not to be an option, we will use ordered logistic and/or logistic regression techniques.

registration_responses.q1: Perceptions of Security and the Sources of State and Non-State Legitimacy in Post-Conflict Settings
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data
registration_responses.q15: The problem for states with limited capacities is that they must gain legitimacy in order to generate compliance and cooperation, often during or after conflict. This project investigates how de-facto and perceived security provision affects perceptions of the legitimacy of governance actors. In particular, our research seeks to answer two questions: What are the sources of legitimacy in areas of limited statehood? What is the relationship between perceptions of security and legitimacy? We articulate a set of hypotheses about the sources of legitimacy and test them with a survey implemented in Liberia. The study will build on previous research and existing theories about the sources of legitimacy. The project focuses on output-based theories of legitimacy and the extent to which effective governance allow authorities to build perceptions of legitimacy among local populations. Specifically, the project investigates the degree to which perceptions of physical security within local populations can function as a source of legitimacy, since security perceptions are an essential part of effective governance. Moreover, the project will also consider alternative sources of legitimacy such as procedural justice or democratic input-mechanisms. Thereby, the study contributes to the debate about which sources of legitimacy are most relevant and allows for comparisons between varying sources. The project takes the legitimacy of state institutions on different levels in to account (local vs. county-level), but also the legitimacy of UNMIL troops as external actors. Therefore, comparisons between different actors and institutions will be possible. We selected Liberia because the state’s limitations in Liberia make it possible for us to generalize our findings to other settings with limited statehood.
registration_responses.q16: H1a: Individual perceptions of procedural justice are positively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive county-level state institutions as legitimate. H1b: Individual perceptions of procedural justice are positively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive local state institutions as legitimate. H1c: Individual perceptions of procedural justice are positively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive UNMIL troops as legitimate. H2a: Individual perceptions of democratic processes as free and fair are positively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive county-level state institutions as legitimate. H2b: Individual perceptions of democratic processes as free and fair are positively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive local state institutions as legitimate. H2c: Individual perceptions of democratic processes as free and fair are positively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive UNMIL troops as legitimate. H3a: Individual perceptions of corruption are negatively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive county-level state institutions as legitimate. H3b: Individual perceptions of corruption are negatively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive local state institutions as legitimate. H3c: Individual perceptions of corruption are negatively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive UNMIL troops as legitimate. H4a: Contact with state institutions is positively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive county-level state institutions as legitimate. H4b: Contact with state institutions is positively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive county-level state institutions as legitimate. H4c: Contact with state institutions is positively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive local state institutions as legitimate. H5a: Contact with state institutions decreases the likelihood that citizens perceive local state institutions as legitimate. H5b: Contact with state institutions increases the likelihood that citizens perceive UNMIL troops as legitimate. H5c: Contact with state institutions decreases the likelihood that citizens perceive UNMIL troops as legitimate. For our main hypothesis, we theorize that when civilians feel more secure, they perceive state institutions and UNMIL troops as more legitimate, conditional on individuals explicitly attributing their security to these actors. H6a: Individual perceptions of security are positively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive county-level state institutions as legitimate. H6b: Individual perceptions of security are positively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive local state institutions as legitimate. H6c: Individual perceptions of security are positively associated with the likelihood that citizens perceive UNMIL troops as legitimate. We explicitly test for the conditional aspects of our main hypotheses: H7a: Individuals that explicitly attribute their security to state institutions are more likely than those who do not to perceive county-level state institutions as legitimate. H7b: Individuals that explicitly attribute their security to state institutions are more likely than those who do not to perceive local state institutions as legitimate. H7c: Individuals that explicitly attribute their security to UNMIL are more likely than those who do not to perceive UNMIL as legitimate. We also want to test whether the legitimacy the UNMIL troops possibly enjoyed had positive externalities on state institutions. Since one of the main goals of the UNMIL troops was to help build state institutions and a functioning state-society relationship. These hypotheses help to test one of the core assumptions behind external intervention aiming at state-building. H8a: Citizens that consider UNMIL troops as legitimate are also more likely to perceive county-level state institutions as legitimate. H8b: Citizens that consider UNMIL troops as legitimate are also more likely to perceive local state institutions as legitimate.
registration_responses.q17: We will test the hypotheses with an analysis of survey data collected using SMS surveys implemented with Random Digit Dialing (RDD) methods. Our collaborators at Orange Door Research partnered with a firm called GeoPoll, which has a large sample of Liberian phone numbers, which we used to conduct the nationally representative SMS surveys. GeoPoll has established a partnership with Liberian TelCos, which enables GeoPoll to randomly sample from a full mobile subscriber database of network providers, including the ability to draw random, pre-stratified samples for specific sub-national geographic areas. For this project, and under guidance and supervision from Orange Door Research, GeoPoll randomly sampled respondents from its subscriber database according to the geographic specification provided by Orange Door Research. q1.value: The Effect of Humanizing Knowledge in the Context of Political Partisanship 1B

q2.value: Jonah Koetke, Beverly Conrique, Karina Schumann

q3.value:
(This is a re submission of a previous registration. In our previous registration, we described two studies that would be run, 1a and 1b. After completing study 1a as planned, the results indicated that we should alter study 1b to be more helpful. This change in study 1b is happening before any of the data for 1b has been collected.)

The current political landscape has been extensively researched over the last few years. Numerous studies are currently pointing to increased polarization (Pew, 2014), feelings of value violation (Brandt, Reyna, Chambers, Crawford, Wetherell, 2014), and general intolerance (Crawford and Pilanski, 2014) between liberals and conservatives.

This trend towards uncivil and unproductive partisanship has led many researchers to look for ways of reducing interparty bias.

In this study, we are adding to a new line of research examining the nuances of learning about an outgroup member. Previous research of the Contact Effect has shown preliminary support for the impact of learning about another on bias reduction (Pettigrew and Tropp 2006; 2008).

In this study, we are building on study 1a, exploring further the effect of reading humanizing information. In study 1a, we found support for our hypothesis that reading humanizing knowledge about a political outgroup member would reduce prejudice towards this individual. Counter to our second hypothesis, we found that when the political cue is presented does not matter to the effectiveness of the humanizing narrative. Therefore, in this second study we wish to ask if knowledge about an outgroup member is always helpful, or if it has to be humanizing knowledge.

q4.value:
H1: Knowledge of a political outgroup member will increase participants' humanization towards this member.

H2: Humanizing Knowledge (containing life narrative/arc, social roles, and personality traits) will be more effective in reducing partisan bias than knowledge without these elements.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Study 1b will also have an experimental design very similar to that of 1a. In 1b, however, the location of the cues as a manipulation will be removed, as study 1a showed this to be irrelevant. Likewise, the control for study 1b, instead of being only political information like in 1a, will be another narrative that contains no humanizing information. Participants will be randomly placed into one of four conditions (Humanizing Narrative vs. Not Humanizing Narrative, and Political information included vs. not included) . As there are less conditions, we also will reduce the number of participants in 1b to 400. After reading these narratives, participants will complete a number of self-report dependent variable measures.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly placed into one of four different conditions (Humanizing Narrative vs. Not Humanizing Narrative, and Political information included vs. not included) .

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Prolific Academic, an online recruitment platform. Participants will read a Short Study Description (attached). If interested, they will be given a link to the survey. Upon clicking our link to the Qualtrics survey, potential participants will see the Informational Script (also attached) giving details about the nature of the study and their rights as participants. At this point, they will continue onto the actual study only if they agree to participate. Participants will be payed $2.00 for participation. This will be reflected on the Prolific recruiting form (attached).

q14.value:
For study 1a, we completed a power analysis in the software "r" using the "pwr" package (Champely, 2018) which utilizes the guidelines set out by Cohen (1988). In this analysis, we determined that to have a medium effect size using an ANOVA analysis with 6 groups, with a significance level of .05, and a power of .95, we would need a sample size of at least 324 participants. We opted for a larger sample to allow for the possibility of testing interactions with participants' political orientation.

For 1b, we have opted for a smaller sample size given the reduction in conditions, and the success of finding meaningful effects in 1a.

question.value: Participants, when they begin the survey, will be asked to read a narrative about a fictitious person. After reading this narrative they will be asked to fill out a number of measures assessing their perceptions of the person in the narrative. This narrative (attached) has four potential variations  (Humanizing Narrative vs. Not Humanizing Narrative, and Political information included vs. not included).

Before the narrative, participants will be asked to fill out survey items measuring their Implicit Theories of Empathy and Groups. After the narrative they will fill out survey items measuring their levels of threat, dehumanization, hypothetical empathic effort, negative affect, perceived morality, and intergroup anxiety. Following this, the participants will be asked some demographic information such as political party affiliation, age, gender identity, etc. In this version of the study, we are adding one additional item to the Dehumanization scale, so as to also assess how generalizable the effect is to political outgroup members in general.

We will be exploring with factorial ANOVAs using the variables humanizing vs. non-humanizing, and political vs. not political. We will be examining the effects these conditions have on the variables of, Negative Affect, Empathic Effort, Intergroup Anxiety, Ascent Dehumanization, Perceived Morality, and Symbolic Threat.  We will also be exploring the potential mediating abilities of Implicit Theories of Empathy and Implicit Theories of Groups. All of these analyses will be controlling for demographic measures.

q21.value: We will be using an alpha value of .05 as our cutoff criteria. All analyses will be two-tailed.

q22.value: There will be an attention check question embedded in the survey.  All those that fail this question will be removed from the analyses.

attributes.title: A Preference for Error-Inducing Price Complexity

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: A preference for costly complexity: mixed-disclosure study jan 2020

other.value:
Any contrasts between aforementioned conditions but not mentioned as supporting hypotheses may be explored in secondary analyses.

We have collected 108 observations as part of a set of two "soft launches" to test the survey. Due to a randomization error, the first 54 observations will be thrown out. The next 54 observations will be included in the ~900 observation study. This is a very small proportion of the total 900 observations, and we cannot derive any substantial insights from the soft launch.

sample.value: ~900 participants will be recruited (54 of which have already been collected)

analyses.value:
We will use proportions tests and logistic regressions with binary outcomes to identify:
1)Whether or not the proportion of individuals choosing a product with a complex disclosure is significantly greater than 50%. Specifically, we will look at conditions in which participants view a simple and a complex disclosure; if the proportion of participants selecting the complex disclosure is greater than 50%, then we will have found support for H1.
2)Whether or not the proportion of individuals choosing the higher-priced option differs across mixed-disclosure vs. single-disclosure conditions. Specifically, we will compare conditions with at least one complex disclosure to conditions either with two simple or two combo disclosures. We anticipate that the former set will lead to more participants selecting the higher-price option than the latter set of conditions, supporting H2. (We have a weaker prediction that mixed-disclosure conditions could lead to a higher likelihood of selecting higher-price options even over the condition in which participants view two complex disclosures.)
3)We will also test the effect of adding a financial incentive; we anticipate that participants will be more likely to select higher-price options (especially when there is at least one complex disclosure in the selection set) when there is no incentive than when there is an incentive, supporting H3.

outliers.value:
We will exclude participants who do not answer key dependent variables. 
In robustness checks, we may also exclude participants who do not pass an attention check and/or whose location cannot be verified to be unique.

Finally, see the note below about excluding the first 54 participants.

dependent.value: Product choice. Participants will have a choice between two products with different price disclosure formats and/or total prices. Choices will be categorized by (a) selecting the higher- or lower-price option, and (b) whether the selected option was more or less complex.

conditions.value:
Participants will be assigned to sets of conditions:
1) Scenario: Participants will be making decisions either about wedding venues, closing fees on the purchase of a property, or prepaid cards. 
2) Incentive: Participants will be incentivized with a bonus (or not) to choose the lowest-price option.
3) Disclosures: Participants will view two products, each with a simple, complex, or combo disclosure. Hence, participants will see either:
a) Complex + simple
b) Complex + combo
c) Simple + Combo
d) Simple + Simple
e) Complex + Complex
f) Combo + Combo
In each case, one option is more expensive than the other; hence, (a)-(c) need to be counterbalanced such that participants see either one disclosure type as the more expensive option or the other. (For example, participants assigned to condition (a) will see either (i) a complex and expensive product and a simple and cheap product, or (ii) a complex and cheap product and a simple and expensive product.) Because conditions (a)-(c) need to be counterbalanced but conditions (d)-(f) do not, we will recruit double the participants for these conditions.

hypothesis.value:
H1: Consumers are more likely to choose products with complex disclosures (over simple disclosures) even though these disclosures lead them to pay more.

H2: Consumers will be more likely to choose higher-fee products when selecting between a mix of disclosure types (if there is at least one complex disclosure) than if both disclosures are in a simple or combo format. 

H3: A financial incentive will decrease the proportion of participants who select higher-price options (especially in conditions with at least one complex disclosure).

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Need for Structure and Self-Construal as Predictors of Punitive Judgments

sample.value: 600 participants will be recruited from Amazon's mechanical turk.

analyses.value:
We will conduct a series of linear mixed effects models (LMEMs). In each model, participant and principle will be included as crossed random effects.

Model 1: Personal need for structure predicting punitive judgments.
Model 2: Interdependent self-construal predicting punitive judgments.
Model 3: Independent self-construal predicting punitive judgments.
Model 4: Personal need for structure and interdependent self-construal predicting punitive judgments.
Model 5: Personal need for structure and independent self-construal predicting punitive judgments.

If there are interactions in models 4 and/or 5, we will conduct simple slopes analyses.

outliers.value: The study ended with an attention check question: “Do you feel that you paid attention, avoided distractions, and took the survey seriously?” Participants selected one of five answers: (1) no, I was distracted; (2) no, I had trouble paying attention; (3) no, I didn’t not take the study seriously; (4) no, something else affected my participation negatively; or (5) yes. Participants were assured that their responses would not affect their payment or their eligibility for future studies. Only those participants who selected (5) were included in the analyses.

dependent.value: Participants will be presented with 12 different moral principles. For each principle, participants report how much a person who violates the principle should be punished (1 = not at all, 6 = very much).

hypothesis.value: Do personal need for structure, interdependent self-construal, and independent self-construal separately predict punitive judgments for moral principle violators? Does personal need for structure interact with interdependent self-construal in predicting punitive judgments for moral principle violators? Does personal need for structure interact with independent self-construal in predicting punitive judgments for moral principle violators?

attributes.title: Do cues to traits covary with cues to identity?
attributes.description: The current study will extend upon a previous study conducted by this research team (https://osf.io/g3euq/). This study will investigate the extent to which facial cues that inform trait impressions covary with facial cues associated with identity. In this experiment, participants will be asked to judge 220 face images on a perceived social trait (trustworthiness, dominance, or attractiveness). Participants will be presented with 11 sets of 20 face images and will be told that images within a given set belong to the same identity, however, some sets will in fact contain two different identities. Participants will also complete two short questionnaires pertaining to beliefs about the stability of personality traits.

q1.value: Do cues to traits covary with cues to identity?

q2.value: Taylor Gogan, Jennifer L Beaudry, Julian Oldmeadow

q3.value: The current study will extend upon a previous study conducted by this research team (https://osf.io/g3euq/; which we will refer to as study 1). This study will investigate the extent to which facial cues that inform trait impressions covary with facial cues associated with identity. In this experiment, participants will be asked to judge a series of face images on a perceived social trait (trustworthiness, dominance, or attractiveness). Participants will be presented with 11 sets of 20 face images and will be told that images within a given set belong to the same identity, however, some sets will in fact contain two different identities. Participants will also complete two short questionnaires pertaining to beliefs about the stability of personality traits.

q4.value:
Research questions 
1.	Does believing that face images belong to the same person influence the variability of trait impressions?
2.	Do cues to traits covary with cues to identity?


Hypothesis 1: Trustworthiness will display greater variability in judgements than dominance, which in turn will vary more than attractiveness. 

Rationale: Based on findings from study 1, we expect to replicate with a different sample. Additionally, past research suggests that attractiveness judgements are largely derived from stable cues whereas trustworthiness and dominance and driven more by transient cues which would change across images of an identity (Hehman, Flake, & Freeman, 2015). 


Hypothesis 2: Ratings will vary more for the mixed-identity blocks than the same-identity blocks for attractiveness judgements, with minimal differences for trustworthiness and dominance.

Rationale: Cues to identity will vary more in the mixed-identity image sets than same-identity sets because the former contains images of two different people. Therefore, traits which are thought to be more tied to stable cues (e.g., attractiveness) would vary more in the mixed compared to same identity sets. Traits which are associated with changeable cues (e.g., trustworthiness) should not display meaningful differences in variability between the type of image sets. Additionally, participant beliefs about the stability of traits may explain some of this relationship. If participants believe that traits are not malleable, they might provide similar responses regardless for all the images of an identity. 


Hypothesis 3: We expect to find less variability in all three trait impressions when it is known that the images belong to the same identity (current study) than when it is unknown (study 1).

Rationale: In everyday life people are generally aware that different images belong to the same unfamiliar face (e.g., looking at someone’s Facebook page). However, researchers tend to randomise images, so the participants do not know which images belong to which identity (or even that there are different images of the same identities). To the best of our knowledge, researchers have not tested trait judgements when the identity of the images is known, for unfamiliar faces. If traits vary independently to identity, then awareness of the identity should not influence the variability of trait judgements.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A 3 (trait: trustworthiness, dominance, attractiveness) by 2 (image set type: same or mixed identity) by 11 (image set number) by 20 (image) mixed design will be conducted. Trait dimension will be a between-subjects factor; this will avoid carryover effects between different traits (Rhodes, 2006). Participants will be randomly allocated to one of the three trait judgement conditions where they will rate all 220 images on a given trait. The remaining independent variables will be within-subjects. Images will be presented in 11 blocks, each containing 20 images. Six of these blocks will consist of images from two identities with the remaining five consisting of a single identity.

q9.value: Three aspects of the experiment were randomised. First, participants were randomly allocated to rate all images on either trustworthiness, dominance, or attractiveness. Second, the order of the image blocks was presented in randomised order. Third, the presentation order of the images within each block were completely randomised.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: We have screened for invalid participants, as such, only data pertaining to participant exclusion criteria (e.g., failing the manipulation check) were viewed. However, no analyses or data sorting was conducted. Therefore, we have not view, sorted, or analysed any of the data relating to our hypotheses.

question.value: Data was collected online via Qualtrics survey platform. Convenience sampling was used to recruit participants through a Research Experience Program at Swinburne University of Technology. Undergraduate students were compensated 0.5 course credits for participation; however, participation was completely voluntary. Participants had to be over the age of 18 and must not have completed study 1. Data collection commenced in October 2019 and continued until the required sample size was reached.

q13.value: The final sample consisted of 94 participants who rated 220 face images on a given trait (20,680 data points). A multilevel design will be used with 3 units collected at the trait level, 11 units collected at the image set level, and 220 units collected at the image level.

q14.value: Sample size calculations were based upon computer simulations from Jones et al. (2019), which determined that at least 25-30 raters for each trait (75-90 in total) would ensure adequate power (see https://osf.io/x7fus/ for their code and data). However, we anticipated that the deception would be ineffective for some participants; conservatively it was estimated that 20% of participants would be aware of the deception. As such, it was anticipated we would need to test up to 108 participants to obtain a valid sample of 90.

q15.value: After gathering data from the first 10 participants, data collection was halted to assess the effectiveness of the deception. Only responses for the awareness check item were observed; no analyses were performed at this point. The deception was deemed successful if at least 6 of the first 10 participants passed the awareness check. If the deception was not effective, we would terminate data collection and alter the design of the study. As 8 of the first 10 participants passed the awareness check, data collection recommenced. We ceased testing once we reached 94 participants who passed the awareness check (i.e., were not suspicious of the manipulation) and data screening (e.g., inattentive responses).

question.value: There are two manipulated variables in this experiment. First, participants were randomly allocated to one of three trait judgement conditions (trustworthiness, dominance, or attractiveness). Second, the sets of images consisted of either a single identity or two identities. That is, 5 of the blocks each contained 20 images of a single identity, whereas 6 of the blocks were comprised of 10 images of one identity and 10 images of another. Participants were led to believe that each of the 11 blocks contained images of only a single identity. Identities in the mixed blocks were paired based on general similarity of appearance (e.g., hair colour, age).

Rating scores:
Participants rated each image on a given trait (trustworthiness, dominance, or attractiveness) with ratings ranging from 1 (not at all) to 9 (very). For example, a face was presented, and participants were asked “how trustworthy is this person?”. We will use these ratings to create variability scores for each image (see Indices section). 

Implicit person theory scale:
Chiu, Hong, and Dweck’s (1997) implicit person theory scale measures beliefs regarding the extent to which personal attributes, as a whole, are malleable (incremental theorists) as opposed to fixed (entity theorists). The eight items from their scale are rated on a 6-point scale ranging from 1 (very strongly disagree) to 6 (very strongly agree), with higher scores reflecting an entity view of personality and lower scores consistent with an incremental theory of personality. Each of the items are listed below: 
1.	The kind of person someone is, is something very basic about them and it can’t be changed very much.
2.	People can do things differently, but the important parts of who they are can’t really be changed.
3.	Everyone, no matter who they are, can significantly change their basic characteristics.
4.	As much as I hate to admit it, you can’t teach an old dog new tricks. People can’t really change their deepest attributes.
5.	People can always substantially change the kind of person they are.
6.	Everyone is a certain kind of person, and there is not much that can be done to really change that.
7.	No matter what kind of person someone is, they can always change very much.
8.	All people can change even their most basic qualities.

Stability of traits scale:
The stability of traits scale is an adaption of Chiu et al’s. (1997) scale which will be used to target to the specific traits of interest for this study. People might not hold the same beliefs for different personality traits. The nine-item questionnaire is rated on a 6-point scale ranging from 1 (very strongly disagree) to 6 (very strongly agree), with higher scores reflecting an entity view of personality and lower scores consistent with an incremental theory of personality. Each of the items are listed below:

1.	A person’s trustworthiness will remain relatively the same from one situation to the next. 
2.	A person’s trustworthiness will differ depending on the context 
3.	Trustworthiness is relatively fixed and tends not to change
4.	A person’s dominance will remain relatively the same from one situation to the next. 
5.	A person’s dominance will differ depending on the context 
6.	Dominance is relatively fixed and tends not to change.
7.	A person’s attractiveness will remain relatively the same from one situation to the next. 
8.	A person’s attractiveness will differ depending on the context 
9.	Attractiveness is relatively fixed and tends not to change

Variability scores:
These scores will allow us to assess the extent to which image ratings vary across different traits and image sets. For each identity, we will subtract each participant’s rating score of each image from the participants’ mean score of that identity. We will use the absolute value of these scores because we are only interested in the extent of the variation, not the direction. For example, if a participant gave a rating of 5 for an image and their mean rating score for the identity of that image was 3, the image would have a variability score of 2. As such, for each identity, every participant will have a variability score for each image, which will reflect the degree that image’s rating differs from the mean of the identity. 

Questionnaires:
Both the implicit person theory scale and the stability of traits scale will be computed into composite scores for each participant. The implicit person theory scale items which were reverse coded will be converted (e.g., a score of 1 will be coded as 6). The item scores will then be aggregated and then divided by 8 to produce a mean composite score for each participant. The stability of traits scale will also be computed in the same manner. However, a composite score will also be calculated separately for each of the three facets (each of the trait dimensions) in addition to the entire scale.

We will primarily analyse the data using Rstudio (R core team, 2019). We will employ linear mixed effects models to investigate hypotheses 1 and 2 using the ‘lme4’ package (Bates, Maechler, Bolker & Walker, 2015). 

Participants are nested in traits as they were randomly allocated to rate images on only one trait. Additionally, images are nested within identities because each identity consists of 20 images. Trait type (trustworthiness, dominance, and attractiveness), image set type (same or mixed identity), image set number (1-11), and the stability of traits scale will be entered into the models as fixed effects. Participants will be entered as a random effect in all of the models. The dependent variable will be the computed variability scores. We will build the models in a stepwise fashion starting with the null model and adding different combinations of fixed effects for each subsequent model. We are particular interested in whether trait type, image set type, and the interaction of trait type and image set type significantly fit the data. 

A likelihood ratio test will be performed using analysis of variance to compare between the models. Models which are significant or have the lowest AIC values will be considered to best fit the data as this does not penalise model complexity to the same extent as BIC (Kuha, 2004). 


To address hypothesis 3 (to compare variability in trait ratings between studies), a separate between-subjects analysis of variance will be performed to compare between study 1 and the current study. Only the images used in same identity image sets will be included in this analysis for consistency between the studies. We will test for a main effect of identity awareness (i.e., study 1 or the current study) to determine whether ratings will vary less when the identity of the images is known (current study) as opposed to unknown (study 1). We will also test for an interaction between identity awareness and the type of trait to assess whether being aware of an identity has a different effect across different traits. Following a significant main effect, planned comparisons will be performed within each trait across studies. 


Pearson correlations will be conducted between the Chui et al’s implicit person theory scale and our stability of personality scale (along with each of the facets) to establish validity. We expect moderate to strong positive correlations between the two scales and the facets of our scale and Chui et al’s scale. Additionally, cronbachs alpha will be computed to assess reliability of responses for each scale.

q20.value: We do not anticipate that transformations will be needed.

q22.value: First, participants were removed if they indicated awareness of the deception (i.e., that some blocks actually contain two identities). Second, participant data were excluded if they indicated either moderate or high familiarity with at least one of the identities presented and/or are able to name the identity. Third, data was removed if participants opted for their data not to be used. Moreover, if more than 25% of responses from a given participant were missing, their data was removed. Finally, participants were removed if their identical rating threshold is > 75%.

q23.value: Any missing cases will be replaced using estimation maximisation, after confirming they are missing at random. However, as outlined in the ‘data exclusion’ section, participant data will be removed if more than 25% of responses are missing.

q24.value: We may conduct exploratory analyses to investigate whether either participant gender or face gender are systematically related to trait ratings. No specific hypotheses are advanced.

attributes.title: Second-in-Command Hierarchy
attributes.description: We are examining the impact of a second-in-command hierarchy on perceived flatness, team empowerment, and team performance. The two moderators that we are exploring are the tail / base structure and shared vision / vision alignment.

q1.value: The Effect of Second-in-Command Hierarchy on Perceived Flatness, Empowerment, and Team Performance

q4.value:
Although incorporating the second-in-command in a group creates steeper hierarchy, there is more perceived flatness and / or empowerment when the tail / base structure below the second-in-command is more dispersed / resembles more of a pyramid (compared to a ladder). This contributes to better team performance. 

The second-in-command bridges the differences between the top and the bottom levels in a hierarchy. Exchanges are more easily made because the second allows for influence to flow down the hierarchy and for people at the bottom levels to feel comfortable or empowered to speak up, that is voice their thoughts and opinions. Therefore, it seems like the group is more horizontal or flatter. Without the second-in-command, there is a big difference between the top and the bottom of a hierarchy. There is a leader, there are group members, and there are no in-betweens. The second-in-command introduces a ladder-step rank. With the second-in-command, there are ladder-like and pyramid-like tail or base structures. The second-in-command increases perceived flatness in a group when the tail end of the hierarchical structure more decentralized, that is, less vertically rigid. This is applicable in groups with at least three layers, the second-in command being the second of the three layers. Note - there must be someone at the top and someone or some people at the bottom. This research does not apply to groups with little to no differentiations (e.g., teams with shared or collective leadership). Although we are looking at small groups (teams), this research could be applied to larger organizations (with boundary conditions to be examined in future research). We are also looking at team empowerment as a mediator and shared vision / vision alignment as a moderator.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: For the MTurk survey design, we will randomly assign participants to two to three conditions at first. For the possible control condition, there is a leader and the rest of the team is on the same level. Then there are two conditions in which the base structure of the hierarchy is different, but both have a leader and a second-in-command. Then the participants will answer survey items about team empowerment, perceived flatness, shared vision / vision alignment, and demographic questions.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We are using Mturk for this first part. Recruitment is done online and via help from the Ross Behavioral Lab coordinator. Subjects will be older than 18 and from the United States. Study timeline for this first phase is one year (most likely less).

We are measuring based on survey items: perceived flatness, team empowerment (slightly altered from Kirkman, Rosen, Tesluk, and Gibson, 2004), and shared vision/vision alignment (adapted from Journal of Environmental Management, 2008, Alberto Aragón-Correa).
We think we will be using regression and ANOVA.

registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q8.question: For the MTurk survey design, we will randomly assign participants to two to three conditions at first. For the possible control condition, there is a leader and the rest of the team is on the same level. Then there are two conditions in which the base structure of the hierarchy is different, but both have a leader and a second-in-command. Then the participants will answer survey items about team empowerment, perceived flatness, shared vision / vision alignment, and demographic questions.
registration_responses.q12.question: We are using Mturk for this first part. Recruitment is done online and via help from the Ross Behavioral Lab coordinator. Subjects will be older than 18 and from the United States. Study timeline for this first phase is one year (most likely less).
registration_responses.q17.question: We are measuring based on survey items: perceived flatness, team empowerment (slightly altered from Kirkman, Rosen, Tesluk, and Gibson, 2004), and shared vision/vision alignment (adapted from Journal of Environmental Management, 2008, Alberto Aragón-Correa).
registration_responses.q19.question: We think we will be using regression and ANOVA.
